article_title: Violin virtuoso, Boulder Philharmonic to fill Macky with romance
article_text:
Grammy-nominated violinist Philippe Quint will play the "Red Violin Concerto" with the Boulder Philharmonic on Saturday. ( Lisa-Marie Mazzucco / Courtesy photo )

If you go What: The Boulder Philharmonic presents "Legendary Love" with violinist Philippe Quint, the fourth season subscription concert for 2014-15 When: 7:30 p.m. Saturday, Feb. 14 Where: Macky Auditorium, 285 University Ave., University of Colorado campus, Boulder Tickets: $13-$70 Info: 303-449-1343 (ext. 2) or boulderphil.org Etc.: Philippe Quint will play for the Phil's Winter Intermezzo Dinner and Recital, 6-8 p.m. Thursday, Feb. 12, at Jill's Restaurant in the St Julien Hotel, 900 Walnut St. He will be accompanied at the piano by Michael Butterman in works by Tchaikovsky and Saint-Saens and will play Corigliano's solo "Caprices" from "The Red Violin." Cost is $100 a person, including full dinner. In conjunction, the film "The Red Violin" will be screened at the Boedecker Theater in The Dairy Center for the Performing Arts, 2590 Walnut St., at 4 p.m. Wednesday and Friday and 7 p.m. Thursday. Cost is $11. Info: 303-440-7826 or thedairy.org.

When Valentine's Day falls on a Saturday, the Boulder Philharmonic Orchestra is there to provide a date night option.

As it did the previous time this happened, in 2009, the orchestra will perform at Macky Auditorium on Saturday. This year, music director Michael Butterman will present a program titled "Legendary Love" to fit with his "Season of Legends"campaign.

In this case, those legends are musical depictions of literature's most notoriously tragic couples. The "Prelude and Liebestod," an orchestral excerpt frequently drawn from Richard Wagner's harmonically groundbreaking opera "Tristan and Isolde," will be paired with Tchaikovsky's "Romeo and Juliet" Fantasy-Overture on the program's second half.

On the first half, the Phil is joined by Grammy-nominated virtuoso violinist Philippe Quint, who plays the "Red Violin Concerto" by American composer John Corigliano, a work whose origins lie in Corigliano's Oscar-winning score to the 1998 film of the same name.

Regarding the Valentine's Day concert, Butterman said that it simply fits the rhythms of the orchestra's schedule.

"One of the dates we usually get Macky Auditorium is that weekend in February, so we embrace it," he said. "There is more than enough great music with romantic content or in a romantic style."

Butterman originally intended for Quint to play Leonard Bernstein's "Serenade," a piece built around the idea of love, but when the Colorado Music Festival programmed that piece last summer, Butterman settled on the Corigliano, which Quint has made a signature concerto.

"I knew I didn't want to do one of the big romantic-era concertos," Butterman said, "and I knew that this was a piece that would fit the program."

Quint played the concerto with the Colorado Springs Philharmonic on that group's opening concert this season.

Speaking with the Camera about the work, Quint said that it was going to become "the next warhorse violin concerto," noting that more and more performers are learning, performing and recording it.

The violinist outlined the concerto's unique origins in the film score and added a personal note.

"During my school days at Juilliard, Corigliano showed up at my music history class to give a lecture," Quint said. "At the time, he had written very little for the violin. In the Q&A, I was bold enough to ask why he hadn't written a violin concerto. He replied that there were plenty of concertos for the instrument, and he wanted to contribute to the repertoire of other instruments.

"Of course, once he was approached to write the score for the film and the great Joshua Bell was engaged to play in that score, things changed rapidly," Quint continued. "Nobody expected that the movie would be such a success, and it created an explosion in the music world. Any film that relates to classical music and becomes a success is big news."

After he won the Oscar, Corigliano was persuaded to use the film score as a launch point for a full concerto, so he employed the "Chaconne," a theme heard throughout the movie, as the first movement. The newly composed second, third and fourth movements also refer to themes from the movie. He finished it in 2002.

"Because of this movie, the world has a violin concerto from one of the greatest living American composers," Quint said.

Bell, of course, did all the major premieres before other violinists picked it up, but Quint has an intimate connection to the "Red Violin" music. He was the first to record Corigliano's Caprices for solo violin, which also come from the score. About the composer's approach to the violin in the concerto, Quint said that "John stretches the instrument to the next level. The soloist, conductor and orchestra can't lose focus for one second."

Quint said the piece obviously fit with the "love" theme of the concert.

"Violinists have a true relationship of love with their instruments," he said, "and that is shown in both the film and the concerto. It's not the first time I've played it on Valentine's Day."

In the "Prelude and Liebestod," the opera's opening and closing music is brought together in a concert piece. The "Liebestod" (literally, "love-death"), originally a soprano solo, is performed either with or without a singer in concert.

"One piece flows into the other, as if he intended it to work that way," Butterman said. "The harmonic tension is never resolved until the end, reflecting the intense progression of the relationship."

The familiar Tchaikovsky composition is a natural concert closer. While its love theme is universally recognized, the overture also includes dramatic, aggressive music that reflects the feud between the families.

Like the Wagner, Butterman said, the piece is structured around the building of romantic tension.
